markdown:
<title
    level="1"
    right="Armor 0"
    pfs="Standard"
>
[Wooden Breastplate](/Armor.aspx?ID=36)
</title>

<traits>

</traits>

<column gap="tiny">

<row gap="tiny">**Source** [Treasure Vault](/Sources.aspx?ID=191) pg. 11 <sup>1.1</sup></row>

<row gap="medium">
**Price** 6 gp

**AC Bonus** +3

**Dex Cap** +2

**Check Penalty** -2

**Speed Penalty** -5 ft.
</row>

<row gap="medium">
**Strength** 14

**Bulk** 2

**Category** Medium

**Group** Wood
</row>

</column>

---

A suit of carved and tempered wood, a wooden breastplate resembles a metal breastplate in shape and function. Such suits can be carved from large pieces of wood, but they most often come from wood coaxed magically from special trees, whether by [druids](/Classes.aspx?ID=6), [elves](/Ancestries.aspx?ID=2), [fey](/Traits.aspx?ID=69), or [plant](/Traits.aspx?ID=125) creatures such as [arboreals](/MonsterFamilies.aspx?ID=8) or [leshys](/Ancestries.aspx?ID=14).

<title level="2">Armor Specialization Effects</title>

<row gap="tiny">**Source** [Core Rulebook](/Sources.aspx?ID=1) pg. 275 <sup>4.0</sup></row>

Certain class features can grant you additional benefits with certain armors. This is called an armor specialization effect. The exact effect depends on which armor group your armor belongs to, as listed below. Only medium and heavy armors have armor specialization effects.

[Click here for the full rules on Armor Specialization Effects](/Rules.aspx?ID=211).

<document level="2" id="armor-group-7" />
name: Wooden Breastplate
